lg.l: Aren’t there three which are proclaimed by those of this earth, which is called
the Lady of the land with water as a border, cloud-covered mountains as [her] breasts,
the spacious seas – [her] dress, the superb sun – a jewel [at her forehead],
a great, red, muddy river – a great necklace on her chest,
and the heavy, dark rains – her tresses?
If examining those three, those who gain that [one]
among these called virtue, wealth, and delight,
will gain the [other] two worthy portions.
state there is another. What they say, even that
is without scrutiny, isn’t it! The way the words, spoken
by people of this world, are without scrutiny, I shall tell [you] that.
Shall [all] listen? Bursting through the orb of the full-rayed [sun],
[its] single-wheeled chariot yoked to seven steeds in the clouds,
can ‘not returning from it’ be one [thing] that ceases?
Besides, leaving a fine rabbit, [would one] go after a crow?
You with fine, young breasts! What happened to me is [this]:
Gathering up my dark hair [and] tying [it], binding [my] glowing breasts
so that a bodice covered [them], straightening my jeweled sash,
[and] wearing kohl powder on my eyes, [like] pointed iron lances,
while I kept catching [and] hitting [my] fine, pretty ball,
as drums thundered [and] so that all people [of] the earth rejoiced,
the one called Māl with red eyes like dewy lotuses,
bearing two fine pots danced in the thriving street
Because of my harsh fate, I went to those with fine, young breasts,
who, seeing that [dancing], asked “Won’t you come?”
[Then] I lost my dark-jeweled coloring and arm bangles.
I [would] not accept anything anyone said. Seeing me who was bewildered
– [my] senses failing with an incurable body, –
pitying [me], my mother, her words like a pretty parakeet’s,
came [and] having protected me with fine, rich powders,
of fragrant, fine kuṟiñci clusters, she offered one thing to Cāttaṉ
[from among] those things she had never offered before! Even with that,
this malady of my mind did not end; my bewilderment did not end.
My complexion did not come [back] either. Moreover, seeing this,
some [grand]mothers of ancient wisdom there spoke:
“If you conduct the fortune-telling that is advised by people,
someone will be revealed,” they said.
a soothsayer with a dark, coiled hair bun, commencing divination,
while grabbing [and] tossing the few paddy [kernels] on a fine winnowing fan,
while sweating, while trembling over and over, while [her] body bristled,
[and] while sniffing [her] hand, she said, “He who has one-thousand names!”
Furthermore, she indicated [his] sacred body like a raincloud. “The thing
in [his] hand is the fine right-whorled conch!” she said.
a fragrant garland of sacred tulasī clusters; while divining [she said],
“You [should] not fear anything! He who made your girl ill
is not [just] anyone! I recognized him [now]!
You of eyes like sharp spears, shall I tell you so that [you] know?
He by whose foot the earth was measured,
by whom Lanka fell as dust [and only] dust,
further by whom the rain of stones was guarded [against],
[and] by whom the sea waters were churned up, see [it is] he!
Becoming one whose nature is insatiable, having grazed the village cattle herd,
[and] having swallowed and spewed out the whole world,
one day there [in] a cowherd village, she with hips [in] a fine girdle,
fine feet, red coral lips, and lovely bodice-covered breasts,
catching hold of a churning rod to tie [it] up,
after having churned fine curds all of one day
so that her lovely sides ached, that simple lady, her brow full of sweat,
utting the butter which had curdled in another pot,
[then] lifting it [to] the rope netting and storing it so that it rested well,
until the time that simple lady went, [her] eyes like battling lances,
[he,] like one who knows nothing, sleeping in a feigned sleep, [then] waking
[and] reaching [his] hands up to [his] broad, garlanded shoulders,
[and] gulping the never-sating butter, [then] toppling a nearby pot full of buttermilk,
in the place [he] had previously lain, he lay like one who knows nothing;
And she who [then] saw [him] as she came [back]
did not see what she had stored; pounding [her] belly [in anguish]
“Who? Who would come in here, except this ’gentleman’?
Yes! You did this!” [thus] saying, with a long rope
so that all those of the village saw, as one of unrelenting rage
tying [him] tightly to a mortar, as [she] beat [him]
with his belly unfilled, he could not bear it. Besides [this],
arriving at a wide, water-filled pond, continuing to harass,
[and] whooping, saying, ‘Come to me’ to a thousand-hooded serpent
with the cruel king’s nature, he leaped onto [that] other’s head
While, with a sharp sword, cutting off
the crooked nose and two ears of her who had come, a night-wanderer,
saying, “I am equal to his Sītā,”
driving [her] away, he [then] bent [his] bow [in] a way
that her elder brother did not reached fiery Hell.
For the sake of red coral-lipped Vaidehī, she with lovely bodice-covered breasts,
severing the fine twice-five heads of Rāvaṇa with handsome, broad-shoulders,
and killing him, red-eyed Māl, who rejoiced,
splitting the chest of the bearer of the long battle spear [whose] name was ‘Gold’
with pointed claws which were sharp, tying the entrails
[like] a garland on his [own] fine, sacred chest, [and] his kumkum-[adorned] arms
beating the one lying [there] while red blood dripped,
he [then] rose up, roaring [in] a lion form. Besides [this],
at the time when he became the one named Vāmana, asking [of] Māvali,
‘Give me three steps [worth] of earth,’ receiving [it with] water through deceit,
stretching, he measured the whole world.
In the never-ending battle [of] the demons and Himself,
setting up a cloud-covered mountain [and] bearing [it] without moving,
[with] a serpent as a rope, He churned [the Sea of Milk], he whose chest is overspread
with a garland of sacred tulasī. When a battle elephant,
like a wide, dark mountain, remaining caught in a pond,
crying out [and] bearing a dewy lotus flower with [its] long trunk,
said, ‘Nārāyaṇā! Jewel-hued One, You [on] a serpent bed,
come; end my harsh pain,’ raging, arriving with unending fury, our great Lord
while splitting [the crocodile ] in two pieces,
He who has one-thousand names, foolish woman,
is the one who caused your girl this incurable illness,” she declared.
Hearing that it was definitely not anyone else, our mother saying,
“You with battling lance-like eyes, if it is he,
will he leave without giving [her] flowering tulasī? Isn’t she his servant?
Is there anyone else?” she ceased.
Because of just seeing his divine body, like a rain cloud,
I do not understand the way that the cool north wind
as soon as it entered while sawing [at] this body, buffeted [it] as [I] swooned.
So that the scorn of that which is voiced by some slanderers with curly hair
would not come [to me], for a defense, I remained silent.
“Come, simple heart, [and] having done so, [whether] the jewel-hued One,
blessing us with a fine, sacred tulasī garland
will not give [it] or give [it] – one of the two –
when speaking, without any detractors hearing that,
if he is considering [it], listening to [this] command,
don’t remain! You must return to me who said [this]!”
[But] even that heart which went after the dark sea-hued [Lord]
without coming [back], forgot me. I, of harsh karma,
became the laughingstock of the town folk.
No other here inquires about me. Like wax in fire,
my soul melts becoming liquid. [My] long eyes
do not sleep, even if the town folk sleep. I babble
only what are the names of the Supreme.
of those whose desire has become like the dark sea
she was not [just] anyone or anything. Look!
As all of her great friends remained, [into] the broad roadway
she followed him of fettered feet and broad, garlanded shoulders;
was she utterly scorned by the town folk?
will any other here, a superior, instruct me? Until I see
his dark, divine body, [I will] go [to]
Ūrakam of walled Kacci and into Pēr
[to] Vellaṟai of the one who broke the maruta tree while moving, [and] Veḵkā,
Viṇṇakaram, the city of dark jewel-hued Kaṇṇaṉ, [and]
cloud-covered Kuṭantai, Kaṭikai, and Mallai [by] the sea,
to Iṭaventai encircled by beautiful gardens, [and] Nīrmalai,
Badarī which is praised by the world, [and] northern Maturā:
[to] all of these which are [his] cities, without leaving [any], him,
who, having broken one elephant’s tusk, removed one elephant’s pain,
the superb One, the red-eyed, tall One,
him with the garland of honeyed tulasī, him with eyes like the lotus -
babbling his one-thousand superb names, difficult to recount,
[into] the broad roadway, even if the town folk condemn [me],
I will not desist from riding the long, fresh palmyra stems.
